# Copilot Instructions for Team Planner

This document provides guidance for GitHub Copilot coding agent when working on this repository.

## Project Overview

Team Planner is a project for planning and managing team activities and schedules.

## Development Environment

### Prerequisites
- Git for version control
- Text editor or IDE with GitHub Copilot support

### Getting Started
1. Clone the repository
2. Read the README.md for project-specific information

## Coding Standards

### General Principles
- Write clear, maintainable, and well-documented code
- Follow existing code patterns and conventions in the repository
- Keep changes minimal and focused on the specific issue or task
- Test your changes before submitting

### Code Style
- Use consistent indentation (follow existing files)
- Write descriptive variable and function names
- Add comments for complex logic
- Keep functions small and focused on a single responsibility

### Git Commit Messages
- Use clear, descriptive commit messages
- Start with a verb in present tense (e.g., "Add", "Fix", "Update")
- Keep the first line under 72 characters
- Add detailed description if needed

## Pull Request Guidelines

### Before Creating a PR
- Ensure all changes are tested
- Review your own changes first
- Make sure commit messages are clear
- Update documentation if needed

### PR Description
- Clearly describe what changes were made and why
- Reference the related issue number
- List any breaking changes or important notes
- Include testing steps if applicable

## Working with Issues

### Issue Assignment
- Only work on issues assigned to you or Copilot
- Ask for clarification if requirements are unclear
- Break down large tasks into smaller, manageable steps

### Task Completion
- Mark tasks as complete only when fully tested
- Update issue status and add comments on progress
- Request review when ready

## Best Practices for Copilot

### Effective Tasks
- Well-defined bug fixes
- Adding tests for existing code
- Documentation updates
- Small feature additions
- Code refactoring with clear goals

### Review Process
- All Copilot-generated code requires human review
- Be prepared for iterative feedback and improvements
- Address review comments promptly and thoroughly

## Security

### Security Practices
- Never commit sensitive information (passwords, API keys, tokens)
- Validate and sanitize all user inputs
- Follow security best practices for the language/framework in use
- Report security vulnerabilities to maintainers

## Testing

### Test Requirements
- Add tests for new features
- Update tests when modifying existing functionality
- Ensure all tests pass before submitting PR
- Follow existing test patterns and conventions

## Documentation

### Documentation Standards
- Update README.md for user-facing changes
- Add inline comments for complex logic
- Document public APIs and functions
- Keep documentation in sync with code changes

## Additional Notes

- When in doubt, ask for clarification
- Prioritize code quality over speed
- Consider backward compatibility
- Be respectful in all communications
